title: R42746
content: The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) held elections for its Legislative Council (Legco) in 2012, leading to the selection of CY Leung as Chief Executive. The newly elected officials will consider political reforms for universal suffrage in 2017 and 2020. However, concerns arise over the Chinese government's influence in the selection process and potential challenges for Hong Kong's democracy. The 2012 Hong Kong elections resulted in a political stalemate due to pro-democracy members blocking election reforms. The outcome is significant to Congress due to the Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 supporting democratization in Hong Kong. The 1990 National People's Congress stipulated the aim of universal suffrage for the election of the Chief Executive and all Legislative Council members in Hong Kong. Scholars suggest Hong Kong could be a testing ground for democratic reforms in Mainland China, signaling China's willingness for political changes. The CCP's opposition to democratic reforms in Hong Kong may prompt Congress to assess and support democracy in the city. Funds have been allocated in the past for promoting democratic practices, and Congress may continue to do so. The Basic Law established an executive-led government in Hong Kong, similar to British colonial rule, with the Chief Executive chosen by an Election Committee. Election reforms in 2010 expanded the Committee to 1,200 members. In 2010, election reforms in Hong Kong expanded the Election Committee to 1,200 members and increased the nomination threshold. The selection of the fourth Chief Executive was set for March 25, 2012, with Henry Tang Ying-yen and CY Leung as frontrunners. Tang received support from 390 Election Committee members, while Leung had the backing of 305 members. Henry Tang Ying-yen, the dark horse candidate supported by 305 Election Committee members, faced various issues during his bid for Chief Executive, including admitting to an affair, allegations of past affairs, questions about his education, and reports of illegal construction on one of his houses. Henry Tang faced issues during his bid for Chief Executive, including admitting to an unauthorized basement with a private movie theater and wine cellar. His dishonesty eroded his image, leading to a shift in public support to Leung. Rumors spread about Chinese government support switching to Leung. The official vote took place on March 25, 2012. Leung won the Chief Executive election with 689 votes, followed by Tang with 285 votes and Ho with 76 votes. He was sworn in on July 1, 2012, amidst controversy for taking the oath in Mandarin Chinese and having Chinese President Hu Jintao preside over the event, raising concerns about his commitment to Hong Kong's autonomy. The Legislative Council (Legco) in Hong Kong has limited power, with members only able to introduce legislation not related to public expenditure or government structure. Legislation is mostly introduced by the Chief Executive. Legco can block legislation and has limited oversight of the government. Before the 1997 transition to Chinese sovereignty, Legco had two types of members. In the 2012 Legco election, 3.5 million eligible voters could cast two votes for the city's 70-member council. In the 2012 Legco election, Hong Kong voters could cast two votes for the city's 70-member Legislative Council (Legco). Voter turnout was 52.3%, higher than the 2008 election, attributed to public discontent with the government's decision on a "national education" curriculum. Chief Executive CY Leung announced a decision regarding the teaching of this curriculum. Chief Executive CY Leung made national education curriculum optional before the Legco election. Concern about recent changes in Hong Kong government policies remains high. Election reforms in December 2010 increased Legco seats from 60 to 70, split between geographical and functional constituencies. Voters could cast two votes in the 2012 Legco election, with a 52.3% turnout. In Hong Kong, voters in traditional functional constituencies could also vote in the new District Council functional constituency, known as "super seats." The political landscape is divided between pan-democrats advocating for a faster transition to democracy and a more independent government, and the pro-Beijing camp supporting a gradual transition and closer ties with China. The 2012 election saw hotly contested seats in Legco, with multiple political parties running slates of candidates to increase their chances of winning. The 2012 election in Hong Kong saw the DAB and Democratic Party running multiple slates. The DAB's strategy of splitting slates was successful, winning 10 seats. The Civic Party won all five of its slates, while the left-of-center parties like People Power and Labour Party also had strong showings. In the 2012 Hong Kong election, Leung Kwok Hung (known as "Cheung Mo" or "Long Hair") won in New Territories East with the most votes. The "super seats" were closely watched, with over 3 million eligible voters. The nomination process favored pro-Beijing parties, but opposition to national education and mainlandization favored pan-democrat candidates. The election reforms in 2010 limited candidates to elected members of Hong Kong's 18 District Councils. In 2010, only elected members of Hong Kong's 18 District Councils could be candidates for the five "super seats." Candidates needed support from at least 15 District Council members. In the 2011 election, four parties won seats, including pan-democrat and pro-Beijing parties. Some parties fell short and might have relied on coalition partners for support. In the 2011 election, candidates needed support from at least 15 District Council members to run for the five "super seats." Seven candidates or slates ran for these seats, with pan-democrat and pro-Beijing parties winning seats. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong are a mix of economic and social groups important to the region, a legacy from British rule. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong were initially created to ensure support for the British Governor, but now they serve to support the Chief Executive. These constituencies have a limited number of eligible voters, including individuals, companies, and organizations. The number of eligible voters varies greatly among constituencies, with some having as few as 132 voters and others nearly 90,000. In the recent election, out of the 30 traditional functional constituency seats, 16 had uncontested winners, while nine had two candidates, and Financial Services had the most candidates with five. In the recent election, Pro-Beijing parties and independents won 24 out of 30 traditional functional constituency seats. Economic Synergy and the Federation of Hong Kong and Kowloon Labour Unions each won three seats, while the New Century Forum won one seat. The pro-Beijing coalition will hold 43 seats in the newly elected Legco, led by the DAB with 13 seats. The pan-democrat coalition secured six seats. The newly elected Legco, led by the DAB with 13 seats, will have the pan-democrat coalition with 27 members. Challenges may arise within both coalitions, particularly regarding differing views on issues affecting Hong Kong's population. Friction is expected between the more moderate Civic Party and Democratic Party and the left-of-center LSD and People Power parties. The election reform compromise in 2010 was based on Articles 45 and 68 of the Basic Law, aiming for universal suffrage for the Chief Executive and Legislative Council members. The reforms followed procedures outlined in Annex I and II of the Basic Law, as well as conditions set by the NPCSC in 2007, setting 2017 as the earliest date for direct Chief Executive election and 2020 for all Legco members. The amended Basic Law sets conditions for altering the selection process for the Chief Executive and Legco, requiring a two-thirds majority of all Legco members and the Chief Executive's consent for any amendments. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress must approve these changes. The amended Basic Law requires a two-thirds majority of all Legislative Council members and the Chief Executive's consent for any amendments to the election process. The process involves a six-step procedure outlined by the National People's Congress Standing Committee. The Hong Kong government must introduce a bill of amendments to the Legco, which must be passed by a two-thirds majority. The Chief Executive must then approve the bill, which will be reported to the NPCSC for final approval. The 2012 Legco election results play a significant role in the process, as the pan-democrats can block any proposal to amend the election process. The Hong Kong government needs approval from 20 members of the pro-Beijing coalition to pass election reforms. The key issues are the nomination process for Chief Executive candidates and the future of functional constituencies. Currently, a candidate needs 150 Election Committee members' support to be valid, limiting candidates to eight. Article 45 calls for a democratic nominating committee. The nomination committee for the Chief Executive in Hong Kong is a key issue in election reforms. The process for selecting committee members and the nomination threshold are contentious, with pan-democrats favoring a lower threshold and pro-Beijing groups preferring a higher one. The existence of functional constituencies is also controversial. The functional constituencies in Hong Kong's governance are a controversial issue. Some argue they are undemocratic and should be eliminated to achieve universal suffrage, while others believe they can align with the goal if all eligible voters can participate. The inclusion of company and organizational votes is also debated, with some seeing it as contradictory to universal suffrage. The status of functional constituencies in reform proposals is crucial as they have at least 12 members. The reform proposal in Hong Kong is significant as 12 functional constituency members must vote for election reforms. Analysts doubt these members will vote to eliminate their own Legco seats. The Chinese government's involvement in approving Hong Kong's election reforms raises questions about its commitment to democratization. Observers suggest Hong Kong could be a testing ground for democratic reforms in China and to showcase the "one country, two systems" policy to Taiwan. The Chinese government plays a direct role in approving Hong Kong's election reforms at two key points. The NPCSC decides if the "actual situation" in Hong Kong supports amending the election process based on a 2007 interpretation of Article 45 of the Basic Law. Additionally, the NPCSC must approve any changes in selecting the Chief Executive and electing Legco members after reforms are approved by two-thirds of Legco members and the Chief Executive. This involvement reflects the Chinese government's stance on Hong Kong's democratization and democracy. The NPCSC's decision in 2007 ended the debate in Hong Kong over universal suffrage for the Chief Executive election in 2012. Pan-democrats pushed for reform, while pro-Beijing parties opposed it. The decision delayed universal suffrage until 2017 for the Chief Executive and 2020 for Legco members, also allowing for an increase in Legco size for the 2012 elections. The NPCSC's decision in 2007 ended the debate in Hong Kong over universal suffrage for the Chief Executive election in 2012. Pan-democrats pushed for reform, while pro-Beijing parties opposed it. The decision delayed universal suffrage until 2017 for the Chief Executive and 2020 for Legco members, also allowing for an increase in Legco size for the 2012 elections. The concept of "one country, two systems" was implemented in Hong Kong to demonstrate to Taiwan that reunification poses no threat to its autonomy and way of life. China promised Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy and to preserve its "capitalist system and way of life" for at least 50 years. Some analysts believe the Chinese government may use Hong Kong to test democratic reforms while maintaining CCP control. They suggest controlling candidate nominations while allowing universal suffrage for the Chief Executive election to give the appearance of democracy. The Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 supports democracy in Hong Kong, with U.S. funding for civil society and democratic practices. The U.S. has expressed disappointment in Chinese government intervention in Hong Kong's governance and hopes for future election reforms. Some NGOs in Hong Kong have reservations about accepting U.S. funding. Some NGOs in Hong Kong have reservations about accepting U.S. funding for civil society development, fearing it may stigmatize them in the eyes of the Chinese government. They suggest that U.S. assistance be carefully designed to avoid interference in Hong Kong's internal politics. The democratization of Hong Kong may indicate China's stance on human rights and civil liberties, especially with new leadership in Beijing. Facilitating democratic reforms in Hong Kong could show China's openness to democratic governance and human rights, while thwarting popular election reforms may signal resistance to democratization. The Chinese government's reluctance to accept democratization in Hong Kong is evident. Congress may consider allocating funds for democratic practices in Hong Kong based on election results and future reforms. Hearings may be conducted to address democracy prospects in Hong Kong.
